annotation.TEXT: While the final boss is just as easy as the rest of the game, I'll throw this out as a forewarning: Prepare for a somewhat sloppy fight. I mostly blame it on Milky Rain, which somehow managed to miss every single shot despite being at close range (for the 2nd attempt at least. Every other use landed a low amount of shots).

In other news, I can't aim with the pencils. At least I won't have to worry about that for the next GnG related thing I showcase...
Terribly obvious foreshadowing indeed, huh?

For this next boss, the green mochi is weak to Ice Lance. The other two...I'm honestly not sure. I tried using the other weapons on both of them, and they didn't really seem to take much damage from anything else. At the very least, it's easy to switch back to the buster and get off some quick shots (and on that note, there's actually a button that lets you immediately default to the buster. I just haven't had a reason to use it up until now).

The only notable shortcomings I can think of are some of the gimmick introductions (specifically the yoku blocks) being iffy, and the inability to jump out of a slide. Even then, I don't think those hurt the game too much. It still holds up pretty well after all this time, and I'd definitely recommend it if you haven't played it yet.

And finally, there's the Shuriken...the one weapon you'll absolutely want to stay away from. It's powerful, but incredibly slow and travels in an awkward trajectory. The fact that you can only have one on-screen at a time is what kills it, though. If you accidentally pick it up, quickly try to replace it as soon as you get the chance.

Back in my original playthrough, I remember saying that this was my favorite boss in the game. It still is, actually. It's just a shame that it's incredibly short (even if you don't cheese it with Ice Lance and Dragon Cluster).

Of course, that's not actually the end. There's still one last thing to do in this game: The special stage. Completing the game once unlocks this from the main menu. Unlike the ones found in MM9 and 10 though, this extra level is something completely different from the base game.

Time to move on to the fortress levels, and incidentally, the last part of the playthrough. I've noticed that it usually takes me at least two videos to do any type of end-game content (typically due to the stages being long or there being two fortresses). Here, that's not really the case. Even if you don't abuse speedrun-esque strategies, these final few levels are still surprisingly short compared to the main game's stages.

And that's (almost) it for Nezumi Man. This is definitely one of the easier fan-games out there, but that doesn't really take away from how enjoyable it is. It's a short, but fun game that doesn't need to do anything too fancy to be notable (rather, it does that with its sheer amount of cuteness).

The Teddy Bear is the equivalent to the lance: You can have 2 on-screen, and they deal average damage. The Pencil meanwhile acts like the bow/arrows, letting you fire off two shots at an angle (and dealing strong damage in the process). The Spoon (which sadly isn't seen here), is basically the dagger. It's somewhat weaker than the lance, but very fast and highly spammable, easily making it the best weapon in this stage.

Just to note: This boss seems to be weak to Ice Lance. I actually forgot this at the time of fighting it, though. Much like the other castle bosses, it doesn't have any invincibility frames after getting hit. You can end this fight pretty quickly if you're good at mashing the fire button in mid-air (which admittedly, I've always had problems with).

I could be wrong about this, but given when this game was made (2009-ish), this may be one of the first fan-games to actively allow saving in-between fortress stages (a feature that more of these games could benefit from, to be honest). Granted, I don't use it here since the fortress is just as easy as the rest of the game. The only slight exception to that might be the next two bosses (and even then, it's only a very small jump in difficulty).

Yup, it's straight up Ghosts n' Goblins (set to weird music). Despite taking influence from a far more difficult franchise, this stage isn't all that tough either. The most notable thing here are the unique weapons, all of which follow the typical GnG traits in some manner.
